awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Loopholes as a window into the learning of meaning
awd_abstract_narration:
Intelligent machines could help achieve major human goals. But even current state-of-the-art machines can catastrophically misunderstand what they were asked to do, resulting in machines that 'do what you asked, but not what you want'. In contrast to these failures of human-machine interactions, from an early age humans can quickly and efficiently communicate their goals, and find ways to cooperate and help. But when people's values do not align, they find ‘loopholes’ to avoid cooperating or complying. Loopholes offer a unique window into the successful but opaque commonsense process of goal understanding. While loopholes are a pervasive everyday concern with real world implications, there is little computational or cognitive research examining this phenomenon. This project means to study the mental processes that allow humans to intuitively and purposefully contort communication in loophole-behavior. This research will help tackle central open challenges in the design of safe intelligent machines and human-technology interactions, and will improve our understanding of the emergence of social interactions.  

Previous research has focused on how children learn to communicate socially and negotiate values, but not on how children and adults handle and exploit value misalignment. This raises a crucial question for cognitive science and human-machine interactions: how do people learn to go from ambiguous communication to the alignment of intended goals, plausible alternatives, and one’s own values? Studies of development are particularly important in answering this question, as the developmental trajectory sheds light on which processes are foundational to this ability and which are brought in piecemeal with greater knowledge and experience. The project combines methods from AI, computational cognitive science, and social cognitive development, and will (1) characterize the emergence and scope of loopholes in the wild with large open databases using citizen-science and public data, (2) build a formal framework informed by the data for modeling the interpretation and (mis)alignment of social goals from sparse statements, (3) validate the framework using controlled experiments with diverse populations to study the evaluation of loophole-seeking from childhood to adulthood, and (4) extend this framework with novel studies on the inferred goals of machines in human-machine interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We’re all familiar with “loopholes”. These are intentional misunderstandings that people use to get around requests. Loopholes show up in literature, law, religion, history, and everyday life. Loopholes are also becoming a serious concern in artificial intelligence, with the dawn of systems that might do “what you asked for”, instead of “what you want”. Despite their importance, “loopholes” have not been formally studied in cognitive science and development. This project examined, for the first time, the cognitive underpinnings and development of loopholes. 

We tested and examined the use of loopholes in adults, children, and machines. In adults, we found that loopholes are a frequent, everyday occurrence in adult life across many different domains, and that loopholes are used in particular in cases of goal-conflict and asymmetric power. We built a publicly available repository of loophole use in everyday life for the use of other researchers, and all our findings and stimuli have been made generally available for the use of other researchers. Based on our findings, we developed a novel computational model of the use of loopholes. We studied this model across multiple experiments and found a good fit between its predictions and people’s behavior, though we also found areas of disagreement that will be important and interesting to study in future work. This model’s code and predictions, and the data and stimuli that tested it, has also been made publicly available. We contrasted our model with current popular “large language models” that are a particular focus point of research and concern for both the public and experts. While the models tested are useful at evaluating loopholes, they still lag behind people in coming up with new loopholes, suggesting both a new area for investigation in people’s abilities and in artificial intelligence. 

As for children, we investigated the use of loopholes across development, collecting novel data from hundreds of families and children using novel methods, including have children respond to the use of loopholes by other children, predict the use of loopholes in other children, and come up with novel loopholes of their own. We established the age of emergence of loopholes, how children evaluate them, predict them, and generate them. We found that loopholes emerge around ages 5-6, then peaks and dies off into teen years. We also collected many examples of loophole use ‘in the wild’ from many parents, and all results, models, analysis, and stimuli have been made publicly available. Our work suggests that loopholes require kids to bring together a diverse set of abilities, including social reasoning, pragmatics, and thinking about other people’s thinking. 

Having met our basic goals in studying loopholes in adulthood and childhood, and coming up with a formal framework of their use, we extended our study of loopholes into other domains, including contrasting neutral and immoral loopholes, the use of loopholes in autistic and non-autistic populations, the humor of loopholes, and the creative search process that people use to come up with new loopholes. Altogether, this project has established loopholes as a novel, fruitful, and impactful field of study that other researchers in cognitive science and artificial intelligence can build on and explore. This work has been presented in professional conferences, discussed both formally and informally by experts in machine learning and artificial intelligence, and published in leading journals. Beyond its scientific merits and broader impact through novel publicly available data, stimuli, methods, and computational models, this project has also supported the intensive training of an academic and scientific workforce, and brought together existing fields of study in a new way.
